l0DFy8zNsB0LG-Ckz5piWQ.text: Everything was delightful. Had no idea about this place, but wanted something good in the neighborhood for a night out. How nice to walk to a delicious meal in a cozy atmosphere. The restaurant was packed but we were able to sit at the bar. Bartender was friendly and charming.   We had the chicken liver mousse to start, which was SO good. Seriously, the I could eat it with a spoon... But luckily it comes with crispy toasted sourdough. :)   Entrees were great, too. I had the tagliatelle and my boyfriend had the pork loin.   We will definitely come back! Great place to take guests to the city who want something off the beaten path but as good as you'd get in any bigger city.

PYt61yviRq8R4-D5BJLt5w.text: To be fair, this place comfortably deserves a full two stars. However, I feel the need to balance out the excessively inflated reviews. Some of these reviewers must have never eaten out before. Pretentious servers and hostesses, limited menu which is not impressive compared with the plethora of fine dining options in Pittsburgh, and a disjointed hipster ambiance which seems better suited for drinking than eating. Speaking of drinking, be prepared to spend $15/bottle in corkage fees if you're bringing your own wine. The waiter might mistakenly compliment your California Cabernet by saying "you can't go wrong with South American." The daunting exposed power panel in the main dining room finishes off the experience.

GulqPDu2tP1cBZ32-qqMGg.text: I came here with my fiance for dinner on a Monday. I really loved the decor, thinking its hip and unique bringing back the old Pittsburgh train station feel. Food though, I don't think it can level to Meat & Potatoes standard...M&P feels more up-scale and more of a True gastropub to me. I ordered the Station Burger, not sure if the meat is the freshest and doesn't seem like they ground their own meat in house. But oh well, I have high foodie standards. Certainly not disappointed but not a wow either, critically speaking :)

GecHTUTvKNCkqaTK7oxaGw.text: A great new hidden gem in Bloomfield. Both of our meals (the tagliatelle and crispy chicken) were excellent in both taste and presentation. The cocktail selection is creative and good as well.  It is a very small space and I'm sure filled up fast on the weekends.

-UbI-p880FplI9dMViRsEg.text: Everything was wonderful, including great service. There is a new appetizer which is a corn custard and it was delicious. The liver mousse pate is always terrific. Save room for the popcorn panna cotta! Curtis is one of the best chefs in Pittsburgh.

zLV94bH8Rv7yT5RRrDlOHw.text: THE WINGS ARE AMAZINGLY DELICIOUS! the service was okay drinks expensive  food not much that appealed to me except the wings. tried a couple things very small plates neat new place to try, wish the wings were a bit cheaper

AXhADgmGrNXY12ie3QdI5g.text: Waited for some time to eat there.  And boy, oh boy am I disappointed... Food: not too bad. Small menu, that's ok; but stuff is unbelievably rude. I mean: rude. 2TvbKvzaXTrlYbkJEwxMKQ.text: Very good service ....wonderful! If I could bring them to Va beach with me I would eat there all the time . The presentation of the food is just fantastic. The taste was even better I have recommended this restraint to everyone who has asked me.

Im-YWcZqQucYpIOm5Eqr3Q.text: Walked into an empty restaurant on a Tuesday night around 5:30 and the hostess immediately asked if we had a reservation.  No, we didn't.  Why not? Because it was Tuesday.. at 5:30.  She gave us some attitude and hesitated to seat us but a manager interceded and told her where to put us.  An hour and a half later, as we were preparing to leave, at least half the restaurant was still empty.    Aside from this, food was ok, overpriced (for sure).  A failed attempt at "fancy".  I don't recommend going here - many other places in the area that are way, way worth your time, including most of the restaurants up and down the street from this one.

QgSR6A4ovylBkpTQ1yS_nQ.text: We love Station. The food is unique and the drinks are amazing. The bar manager Jesse is the reason we keep coming back. He's so kind, makes amazing drinks, and always has the best service. Go for the food and fall in love with the drinks and service. Seriously love this place!

upkCm-0cQkelnq2FlKgSgA.text: I just paid $30 for a gristle-y skirt steak garnished with mayo and deep-fried cauliflower.  The staff were great, but the food was seriously underwhelming. Just go to Butcher in the Rye.  Maybe just come here for drinks.

wGSL9CpGTd6k2gG96No2mQ.text: My fiance and I went to Station for the first time last night. Quick review: Appetizers were so good, dessert was awesome, drinks and entrees were okay. Longer review: We ordered the carrot salad and crispy wings. The carrot salad was delicious, it was seasoned perfectly with harissa and was pretty filling for being veggies. I think when you serve something called "carrot salad" you kind of have to hit out of the park, and Station does. The crispy wings were amazing, albeit a little greasy. They had a simple flavor (olive oil, parm, and chili flakes I think) but were done right. They had a foam-like white sauce drizzled on them that I could eat with a spoon. Our entrees were okay. I ordered the pork steak on the waitress' recommendation. It wasn't bad, just didn't wow me. The pork was cooked well and was served with some sort of mash and a few pieces of homemade pasta. I think the mash was the best part. My fiance ordered the tagliatelle, which we both agreed was good, except it needed salt. There wasn't any salt on the tables, which made us feel like we would be looked down on for asking for it. The panna cotta popcorn was super good, a great combination of sweet and salty, although for the price, the portion was scarce.   Also, to go along with a few other reviews, the staff was pretentious and did not impress me (although the bartender was fun). The two hostesses that were working acted like they couldn't be bothered with seating people (we waited 15 mins past our reservation, even though the table was open). Also, we attempted to put in our app order first because we were hungry but hadn't quite decided on entrees and our waitress told us that the chefs request we put in the order at once so that they can pace our meal. Um, what? I've worked in a kitchen and you can "pace" a meal without having the whole order if you know what you're doing. Pretty surprised by that comment.

oJ8ma_BlRvorOXPMOOMf3A.text: The food was amazing.  I don't care much for chicken and the crisp was flavorful and not greasy.  The "cheeze whiz" was a hearty touch to the pork shoulder.  The tots were questionable at first, but amazing with every bite.

K6zxrKn5OXvC-AyVOtNh0A.text: Very overrated and over-priced. Ordered a standard cocktail that was watered down and tasteless. The fish we ordered that night was very under-flavored and dry. The appetizer was fussy and pretentious but was essentially a dressed up salad. The waiter seemed to be trying her best, but the quality of the food was very disappointing, especially for the price. Seems the price tag is for the buzz and the hype rather than the quality of the meal.

oryOSNEo4XlqLesW5d6-ag.text: The main reason I'm giving 3 stars is the prices/value 15 dollars for a hamburger and fries and 11 dollars for about 5-6 wings left me feeling quite ripped off. They were definitely good but that's such a bad feeling, feeling like you're significantly over paying. And that is the reason I will not return. Also I ordered 3 cocktails from the menu and none were what I would consider strong, i.e. I felt I was paying for the "accessories" in the drink and not the alcohol - again the absolute thing you don't want to feel like you're paying for at a bar. I saw some negative reviews of the service, but I have to say that our server was absolutely excellent, but after a $100 bill I felt like not tipping 20%+ as I normally do for great service but then of course realizing the prices are not the server's fault did so. Point is I want to feel happy about leaving a $20 tip. So I will not return.

wYWtIaCUkkyKtD_VkJ3b7g.text: The restaurant has a very cozy environment. We sat at the bar and the bartender was very friendly. We had 2 small plates: chicken liver mousse and beef tongue, and an entree of steak - all are pretty decent, but I personally liked the beef tongue the best. :) The drinks are good as well. Would recommend!

sS0CE5QW5bmaQxuszaPVsA.text: As soon as I finished my meal at Station, I was already planning my return visit. I have zero complaints. The service was friendly and attentive. The atmosphere is perfect for a date, a get together with friends, or a stop at the bar for 1. xSOEBH0pXKeocaqFas00uQ.text: I love Station. Pittsburgh needed a restaurant of this caliber. The food, drinks, and service are great.

Zl7hVDb0KQavyAYTlj2tJw.text: I always look at Yelp but never review..but after tonight It was needed! Station was absolutely delicious and service was great. You would be doing yourself a disservice to not try

gZ4B2TU8dczDZQWtvU4yzw.text: Absolutely outstanding dinner!  Every dish we had was delicious:  the heirloom squash, the crispy wings, the scallops, the tagliatelle and the calamari bolognese.  Very innovative dishes with great sauces and flavor combinations.   I'd rate this restaurant right up there with the best of the Deshantz restaurants (I loved Tako, thought Pork and Beans was just ok, will be going to Meat and Potatoes tomorrow night).

9iNJzaV3cv0OOELqos2RzA.text: Station was a pleasant surprise and since it had opened I was curious about whether or not it was worth it.  I got the crispy skin chicken breast & thigh and it blew my mind how tender the chicken was. I don't think I had anything close to how good it was. 2PwV3YyDslJSFFvZWHyAEA.text: Good food, great service! Our breakfast was well done and made to order and service was quick and delightful.

QtWHvsD_RXb2Otl_ThJIhQ.text: I came here for dessert. This will be my go to dessert for the entire city.  ...............Caramel popcorn panna cotta................. I don't think people understand how amazing this dessert is! The first time I had it was when the chef presented it at Dinner Lab. It blew everyone away. I'm so happy they are keeping it on the menu. h0tR77nZ_JnmKQ-WzqtOWA.text: I came here for brunch with 2 of my lady friends, the third was unable to make it :-(. We wanted to booze, brunch, and bitch, as we do. We started with 2 bloody marys, and a michaleda. Their bloody marys are SPICY but not overly so, they're rimmed with some smokey spices, they come with a pickled pepper and a pickled beet (?). Both of which I ate. I'm a sucker for briny things. I love their bloody's. They're perfect. I tried the michaleda and really enjoyed it too. I followed up with a margarita. It was very good, not the best I've ever had but I'm really picky about my margaritas.  I ordered their steak and eggs. The steak was cooked perfectly. The "bbq tots" were incredible. I could seriously eat about 20 of them! The bearnaise sauce was really good, very creamy. I'm weird about eggs, I really truly am. These eggs were over easy (or as you 'burghers call it "dippy"). The bread that came with my meal was perfect for dipping and sopping up the warm yolky mess I managed to make.  I would definitely go back, and I quite look forward to having dinner there. I can only imagine it is equally as delish! It's a bit pricey, but I never really mind spending the money when the portions and the food is as perfectly balanced as their was!

xaUDKZt6X1d_8QVAtsTynw.text: So exited our friends brought us to station! We had an incredible meal. The corn and tomato salad was like summer on a plate, fresh and absolutely delicious!  Our group had scallops, hanger steak, and the ribeye, everyone was very pleased with their meals. We also share the popcorn pana cotta...sounded a bit strange, but do not miss this, it's an amazing dessert!  The drinks from the bar are also amazing, super fresh ingredients and very delicious, the Avaition  was one of the best I've had.  Our server Nick was top notch, knowledgeable of the menu, attentive, and easy going with our rowdy group.  Thank Nick for making the night so enjoyable!

JOTn_8z95YRfSowOff4t9A.text: I had a preview of Station at a yelp event at the Children's museum. Out of all the restaurants that were there, Station stood out to me and all it took was a very tasty and earthy carrot salad. They let me know that they were scheduled to open in Bloomfield in July and I've had it on my list to visit.  Last night I had that opportunity and it was great. We were a large group and I called and made reservations ahead of time. They called me the day before to confirm. And when we arrived, we were promptly seated. The chicken wings were off-the-hook delicious. We got the carrot salad that was equally tasty. The Belgian endive salad was okay for me, but the others in my party loved it.  For my main, I had the pork tagliatelle with the farm poached egg. This dish did not disappoint. The pork delivered just the right amount of salt and had enough jus to soak up the pasta.  The restaurant filled up quickly on this Friday night. The noise level was moderate, but didn't interfere too much with normal conversation. Station seems like it would easily become my go-to bar. The only drawback is that I don't live too close to make frequent visits. I'll definitely be back though. Highly recommend this place.

ur4Ordg1ctQt7QZfnAKs_w.text: I found Station on Yelp and immediately added it to my Bucket-list. I didn't know exactly what to expect but talked my brother into trying it out. We entered into a charming little bar area with lots of seating options. It was around 5:15 on a Friday night... there were only a few patrons in the bar/restaurant. We were lead to the dining room which continued the industrial theme of the bar area. I love the industrial look and the low lightening made the place seem cozy and intimate.  They had a nice drink selection. I ordered the Riesling and my brother had the Belgium Snapshot Wheat. I scanned the menu, and realized I should have done some additional research. The menu was very limited. My brother settled for the safe choice of the Station Burger. This was a burger on a Brioche bun, topped with Asiago Fondue, Onion Ring and Onion Jam with a side of fries. ($16)... it was stacked high and took him no time to finish despite it's intimadating size. I opted for something out of my element. The Caramelized Cabbage and Taleggio Ravioli. The cheese ravioli was topped with brussels sprouts, pickled raisins, verjus, and bread crumbs ($22). Delectable! One of those dishes you keep thinking about how good it was the next day.   My advice is to read the menu on their website prior to eating here. If you aren't willing to try something a little different it could be difficult to choose a meal. If you are willing to try something new GO HERE! The atmosphere is perfection and the food is delicious!

U38PHKctwKtHkD7eruQwKQ.text: I stopped by here a couple of Sunday's ago with my wife for my birthday dinner with her.  This wasn't our original choice of restaurant but whenever the first one fell through we were happy to be able to quickly make reservations at Station.  Whenever we finally had made it to Bloomfield and entered the restaurant I was a little confused.  All that I saw was a bar area and a few other tables to sit at.  Whenever we checked in with the hostess she led us to a second room of the restaurant which had some diners and many more tables.  The inside of Station has an industrial feel and I find it rare in restaurants to find painted black walls like they have here.  I decided to start off the evening by having a cocktail and went with the paisley park.  It ended up being a good choice as the drink was flavorful and had a slight tartness to it which I really enjoyed.  Then for my entree I went with the tagliatelle with my wife went with the burger.  My entree consisted of smoked pork, soffrito, a 1 hr egg and some parmesan cheese but it was really my wife's burger that caught my eye.  It looked amazing and she confirmed that it was while allowing me a small taste.  My meal ended up being quite good.  The egg when broken open had a nice a runny yolk that helped to cover the pasta and give some more savoriness.  I also really enjoyed the sauce for the pasta.  It wasn't a flavor that I could properly identify but it was pleasing.  The pork on the pasta was also good since it was cooked properly and had a light smoky flavor to it.  Overall the flavors melded together to make a nice tasting dish.  The bottom line for me is that I would head back here again in the future.  My drink was good and while I enjoyed the food i ordered, I have to admit that I was jealous of my wife's burger.

vI9GuYlmFPb1TW-nael1aw.text: I have been to Station a couple of times and came back for their great crispy chicken wings. My boyfriend and I also love Szechuan peppercorns and were really excited to try the grilled pork rib. Unfortunately, the ribs did not have even the slightly spice to them and there weren't any peppercorns on the plate. We were really disappointed in the flavor of this dish, but the ribs were cooked well and the yogurt sauce was unique.

j59obKY5d4PHbk2uTR-Eew.text: Well, I had HIGH hopes. The place looked cool when we walked in, the decor is modern and clean. The problem immediately was they did not have the air conditioning on and it was ridiculously hot. My table of 8 literally were sweating the entire meal and it was horrible. In addition to that, the waiter neglected our table all night. Forgetting to bring water, not coming back to take drink orders, messing up the bills. And the worst part? The gratuity was already taken out, so we couldn't even decide if the guy deserved a full tip.   The food was very good... the mixed drinks amazing, but because of all of the other issues, we will NOT be going back. What a shame!

AOYSUkRwiruPmEb9rEdDmQ.text: It's hard for me to do this because of the effort they're making, but this place was extremely overpriced for the poor quality of the food, which doesn't measure up to the place's aesthetic and reputation.   Two drinks, three apps, and an entree ran about $100, and I'd say only two of the apps were something we wanted to finish. The drink orders (classic ones anyone should know to make) were both pretty bad, watery and in one case with the liquor I didn't want. A dish of greens and peas just didn't really gel together, and it was hard to imagine what kind of palate would enjoy it. Finally, the monkfish was undercooked to the point where it wasn't edible. By this point so much had gone wrong that it almost didn't feel worth saying anything. It's just negligence.   There was one standout dish, the wings. Among the best I've had. This sounds bad, but even with this unusually bad experience, I'd go back for those.  It could also be that this was a fluke. A friend mentioned loving the steak and wings there. Still, it's unusual for a restaurant to deliver that bad of an experience. I think there are better options.

t40FrOhHF1CFNEj_mg11JA.text: FOOD:  Good food.  I wouldn't say its the best I have had.  Recently moved from Brooklyn, NY, and this place reminds me of Park Slope.  Tried the lamb, and was disappointed. The dishes look good, but the meat had a strong game taste.  The other dinner options did look good though.  Appearance of each dish is on point.   PRICE:  As expected for this quality of food.  Although would say it's a bit more than what you actually get.    ALCOHOL:  Drinks and beer selection are great.  Tried multiple and was not disappointed.  Prices made me feel like was right back in NYC though.   ATMOSPHERE:  Very Hip/Trendy venue. Clean.  Friendly staff.   Would return, only after trying other places first.

bLiBB5pI7LxGEGHPm3opHg.text: Came here for the first time recently. I had asked around before coming but no one I knew had gone so I came with no expectations for the place!   AMBIENCE B+ On the scale of looking hip and trying too hard Station sits squarely in the middle. Why? Because if your seat happens to be facing outwardly from the restaurant interior, you'll be fine. Hip lighting. Hip Windows. Hip tables. If you are facing the interior you'll get an eyeful of other random things that someone thought of. Meh. It felt very sterile for how cookie cutter hip it was. Like someone googled 'how to be a hip restaurant' and then did some Pinterest crafts.  SERVICE A I don't actually remember the service much, but I think that's a good sign. Which means nothing went wrong, I had no complaints, and the matching aprons they all had were not too distracting!   DRINKS A- They were strong. For sure. I got the Son of a Witch which was good enough but felt a little overwrought. It was trying to be new but just tasted like a sweeter boulevardier. Actually now that I think about it I'm pretty sure it inspired me to make boulevardiers the following weekend.  APPETIZER A- We got the corned beef tongue and chicken liver mousse. Can't mess up chicken liver mousse, so that was lovely. Corned beef tongue was such a huge portion and such a dense amount of flavor I ate maybe half of a toast piece before giving up. It's supposed to be a small plate!   MAIN COURSE B+ I struggle with describing my main course. I ordered the Bavette steak medium rare and it definitely came out medium rare. The meat was cooked to perfection. The texture was perfect. Someone knows how to grill! But that's where they should have stopped. Instead it had two different sauce mixtures on it, plus quite a bit of salt. So much so I couldn't actually taste the meat anymore. It was such a weird sensation. My mouth knowing it's a perfectly cooked piece of meat from the texture but feeling like I'm eating pieces of salty garlic aioli. Step back from the sauce squeezer.  DESSERT Did not have dessert since my friend can't have corn and I'm allergic to lavender. And those were the only two options. I was also way too full by that point to have dessert. Those appetizers were the size of what I normally have for dinner.  A friend asked me how it went and all I could say was eh. I genuinely do not know if I enjoyed it or not, which is a weird thing to feel after three hours and a hundred dollars.

CJFjJiUgXmITRD3Gz2ltFA.text: My girlfriend and I decided to have a spontaneous date night. Station had been on our list, so we decided to try it out. This ended up being one of the best meals we've had in Pittsburgh.  The service was absolutely amazing. So we walked in without a reservation because we don't have much insight. We walked in and they told us that the wait would be about 45 minutes without a reservation. We accepted the fact that we were ill-prepared, so we told them that we would try again sometime during the week with a reservation. The host then asked us to wait a couple of seconds and the manager came out and arranged it so that we could sit down right away. Honestly, it was our fault that we weren't prepared and they still accommodated us with a smile. A great start to the night, we were consistently met with friendly service through the rest of the dining experience.  So enough about the service... the food was DELICIOUS. We both got the burger and shared a roasted carrot salad. The roasted carrot salad was absolutely amazing. Well spiced with multiple different textures (crispy fritters, tender carrots, fresh cheese), it was a great starter. Then the burgers came. Oh man... I love burgers. It's hard to find a good burger: fresh meat that is well seasoned and cooked. I've been looking for a great burger in Pittsburgh and this definitely delivered. The burger came medium rare as recommended: the meat was juicy and seasoned perfectly. It had sweet caramelized onion jam, cheese fondue sauce, and a crispy onion ring all between a brioche bun. On the side was double-fried french fries and spiced mayo. Best burger I have had in Pittsburgh (the only other place I can think of that would compare is Butterjoint's burger).  Fantastic food, great service. It didn't take very long to realize that this would be a 5-star Yelp review.  At the end of the meal, the manager came out and spoke with us for a bit. He spoke highly of his chefs and was genuinely excited about his work. This type of passion is rare. The perfect experience we had was due to the teamwork and chemistry the entire staff share. I will definitely come back soon... WITH a reservation.

vighmtcXWJdPl_nmL-fTeg.text: I came back to update a review that I wrote last year because we just had an amazing meal at Station.     There is a corn custard currently on the menu that is one of the best things I've eaten in recent memory.  It's incredibly fresh (due in no small part to the time of year) and flavorful.  When I go back, I may just have this as my meal.  I also had a angolotti of polenta and straciatelli that was also excellent.  I don't often eat meatless meals, but this one was exceptional.  The wine selection is well-edited and Craig the bartender is the best.

anvlCQZIY8ujeho7zyhwcw.text: We've been meaning to get to Station for some time, so I joined my wife and her friend as a third wheel on a Friday night. Reservations were easy enough and the restaurant was full for the entire evening. I wasn't exactly sure how to describe their menu... gastropub? Italian? Not quite sure.  I was pleasantly surprised with their affordable list of wines and tried both the Cabernet and Malbec, both of which I enjoyed. Pretty standard list of cocktails with a focus on bourbon from what I could tell, and a list of 8-10 drafts.  We decided to start with the chicken wings which were some of the most unique ones I've had in Pittsburgh and came from chickens on steroids from what I could tell (they were big, not implying anything else). Crispy/spicy and covered with an oil, cream, and pickled peppers.  For dinner I had a pasta dish with pork (which was ham, was expecting a different preparation but was gladly surprised) and a one hour egg. I had a hard time ordering, but this dish was a pleasant surprise.  We split the two desserts on the menu including the caramel corn panna cotta which was fine enough, and the lavender pound cake. Not overly aromatic, and a unique combination, but not my favorite by any means.  Overall an enjoyable experience!

vRQra84XnAAOZrFDxECB7g.text: Everything was delicious. We had a party of seven so there was some waiting for the food to arrive for each person and that was a bit of a downer. But everyone was so quiet during their entrees and that's always a good sign. I had the seasonal risotto and it was amazing. Couple of flaws, though...my bowl of risotto was $20. The main plates are just incredibly overpriced for Pittsburgh...even by downtown standards.  And multiple times the waiter forgot we had ordered drinks so we had to ask about them...keep people drinking and they'll be happy!

7lDSLOTO0rItWwi228WKnw.text: I went to meet a girlfriend the other night at Station! I can't believe I have never gone! While, I didn't get a chance to eat, the food that I witnessed smelled and looked (read cheesy pasta) amazing!!! -pw1ZnwajCUXFg5_JD2lHg.text: I went on a Thursday night last week when there were about 5 other parties in total at the restaurant.  I ordered the monkfish and my boyfriend ordered the steak.  Even though they were not busy, it took one hour for our food to arrive.  My fish was room temperature just bearable enough to eat, but our server would not have known because he didn't stop back to ask how the food was until 20 minutes into the meal.  My fish was also not cooked completely through.  It was so tough to cut that a piece of fish ricocheted off of my plate to the floor.  The piece that did fall was about 20% of our meal given that the entrees don't include sides: just a few garnishes and sauce here and there.  After I paid my $100 bill, I concluded that I got the kind of service that suggested the folks here didn't want me to come back.  On the bright side the beer I got was pretty good.  They have a good selection of alcohol, but it's a little ridiculous that I was charged $1 for ice.  I'm sure the waiter didn't mention it because it's ridiculous.  Outside of the nice atmosphere of the place, this is a failed gastro pub. (I should have known by the vibe I got from the lack of patrons.) Entrees should not average $25 just to be meager and cold.

8d-J5lFxyejO38nvAq7Zew.text: Station is easily my favorite restaurant in Pittsburgh. I had some family come visit and when I made a list of dishes they had to try in Pittsburgh, Station was the only restaurant that had multiple-must try dishes. For starters, the crispy wings are to die for, and I am not typically a fan of bone in wings. The breeding, the cheese sauce, the extra kick...just try them. The burger is hands down the best burger I've ever had. I will crave the combination of asiago, bacon jam, and onion rings piled on my burger for years to come. Just make sure you come early, as they frequently run out of the burger!!!

wZ6tBtxzLanYIClPLrPMGA.text: Very mediocre experience... the salad was super salty and it was very very loud the day I went there. Friendly staff though.

4xSM8EqD_Prhw_cmib89uA.text: After a meal with some friends, we were looking for a place to chill that wasn't very noisy to catch up. We wandered into Station and knew it was the perfect place!   Staff was friendly and the atmosphere was a exactly what we needed. I was actually surprised how laid back it was for a Saturday night in Bloomfield (me, two friends and Ankur three or four people at the bar). The place itself have a very modern and rustic look that you see a lot of these, but it makes the place more comforting and warm.   We didn't order food, just drinks. Glass of wine was around $8 which is average.   I would definitely recommend this place if you're looking to hang out for an hour or so without a crazy crowd and noise.

p8FyOyN7iKF1Qur6B39YHQ.text: This is a great addition to Pittsburgh's new American cuisine scene. They do what many other great local restaurants do (I'm talking Butcher and the Rye, Eleven, Meat & Potatoes), but they do it very well. I don't think you're going to have any serious revelations here, but you also aren't going to go home unhappy.  The night we visited, I had their specials. First, they offered a lovely sangria, which was a bit sweet for my taste, but which was very nice with the dinner. We shared their wings - nicely done, but a bit overpriced for wings at $11. My dinner partner got the miso-poached apple ($9), which was a TINY amount of very lovely apples, but was served on a giant plate, further emphasizing the ridiculously small portion.  Two of my dinner partners got the Grilled Bavette Steak ($28), which both of them absolutely loved. They were raving about how tasty and tender their meals were. Another friend got the cabbage and taleggio ravioli ($22), which was not the most beautiful dish presentation-wise (brown on brown on brown), but which he enjoyed. He said it was glorified cheese ravioli, but luckily he likes cheese ravioli. I ordered the special, which was monkfish served in squid ink ($28). This was probably the best white-fish I've ever had - it was presented like a ribeye, with the large central bone still in. The flesh was tender, tasty and a delight to eat. I would certainly return for the fish, though sadly this is not on the regular menu.  The wait for our main courses was very long, probably 45 minutes plus from ordering. Luckily my dinner partners and I like each other a lot, and the conversation flowed, but I was surprised that it took as long as it did. I would certainly not recommend coming here and expecting to eat quickly, but on the other hand, that was part of the charm. We did not feel rushed out or hurried.  We finished with the lavender pound cake ($8), which was a very nice pound cake, though I detected very little of the lavender. There was a nice pineapple component, though.  We all left very full, happy with our meal, and having had a very nice long dinner together. I would certainly come back - but! I would probably not order appetizers here. I'd likely steer directly towards the fish and steak options, and away from salads or pastas.  Looking forward to coming back and trying more menu options!

PgDf_HjiI_cvDHLN_fSJDQ.text: Before a concert on Saturday night, my husband, two of our friends, and I all snagged dinner together at Station at 6pm. Finding an available restaurant for Saturday night just a week in advance can be challenging, so I was happy to obtain a reservation here.  Hubby and I had previously been to Station for a Yelp event. We had a great time - food was great, drinks were great, conversation was great, staff was great, the Bulleit Bourbon rep was great. Because of this event - and all of the great reviews - Station has been on my to-return-to list.  The four of us were running about 10 minutes late but were seated immediately as soon as we arrived. I had spent the Yelp event on a cozy leather bench seat in the bar area and got to check out the dining room this time. The decor is trendy and cool, but the temperature was quite chilly (I almost wore my jacket during the meal) and the wood chairs became a bit uncomfortable throughout our hour and a half stay.  I ordered the Duck and White Bean Ravioli. I was expecting a rich, creamy dish, but got the exact opposite. The combination of arugula and a smoky onion broth gave a very bitter flavor to the dish. The ravioli seemed Asian-inspired with a thick pasta, and the duck filling was heavy. I did not enjoy the dish. My husband ordered the Roasted Venison Leg. Based on the description, I expected a large amount of meat with sweet potatoes and gnocchi on the side. Though the dish had nice flavors, the presentation and quantity fell far short of our expectations. A small dinner plate arrived only about one-quarter covered in food. A few ounces of venison sat on the plate with artistic dots (I'm assuming the sweet potato and gnocchi bits?) placed around the petite slices. It looked like a child's size quantity of food that just didn't deliver for the $29 price tag.  Based on the above, I would have given the experience three stars, but unfortunately, the waitress pulled the whole experience down to two. Now the pros... she did what was directly requested of her. The cons? Her energy was less than a zero, and she seemed to make no effort beyond specific requests to help us. The initial bottle of water was delivered, and even after our glasses were nearly empty and only a few ounces remained in the bottle, I had to request more to drink. We were interested in ordering more beers and cocktails but were never asked about it, even when the glasses were clearly empty. When we were asked how we were doing (the only time), she received one response and quickly scurried off again, ignoring the other three people at the table who also had a request. Our food was delivered without the "need anything else right now" check in and we were asked if we'd "like to order dessert" with no offer of a menu or the options. I could go on and on, but the entire meal just felt like the table was exerting effort while the waitress answered only direct commands.  After this recent experience, I am sorry to say that I am not interested in returning to Station at this time, even if that hard to find Saturday evening reservation is available again in the future.

2X3gczMolzIwm9OsxD8BUQ.text: Had dinner here last night with my dad. I ordered the grilled octopus with sweet corn, pickled jalapeno, baby bok choy, and white bean fritters with a bernaise (?) sauce. It was amazing. I've never had octopus that good! My dad got a pork chop with pierogis, which was quite good, but not amazing (but it's also not something I would order, so take my opinion on it with a grain of salt). I also had a Champs Elysees cocktail, which was awesome! It came in a cute little glass and had these amazing layers of flavor. A bit expensive but worth it for the quality of ingredients, skilled preparation and unusual combination of flavors. Will definitely be back!

3mKtrJvIUMhSUsz8y1DsvQ.text: I finally got a chance to try this place and it is one of my favorite of the new Pittsburgh restaurants this year.  I love the cozy atmosphere and ambiance that is made to look like an old train station, with nice details like the tin roof.  The menu has some interesting options and it was hard to make a decision.  We started with the wings which we shared, and they were so juicy and full of flavor let crunch on the outside--some of the best wings I've ever had.  For my entree I had a pasta dish, the Tagliattelle, which was amazing. You could tell that all the ingredients were very fresh, the pasta was homemade, and the egg on top was perfectly cooked. In addition to some of the fancier entrees they also have a nice range of regular bar food like burgers and sandwiches. All of their portions were generous and I felt the prices were reasonable for the amount and quality of the food.  They also have a decent beer draft list and a nice cocktail menu.  I tried one of their cocktails which was excellent. Their brunch menu also looks really good and I want to go back there sometime to try it. This is a great addition to the Bloomfield neighborhood.

LBvBmOmn5WC7U5MgSj0EIQ.text: Came here for dinner with a large group last Tuesday night, and had the place to ourselves. Love the decor and the general vibe. Our waiter was really helpful in listing the vegetarian options for me (note: they also have an off-menu vegan option).  Cocktail selection is fun and interesting: I tried the white negroni, which was a nice twist, especially for a gin lover like me. They also do great classic cocktails - my second drink was a fantastic corpse reviver.  There were a few vegetarian starters, but I chose the miso poached apple since I love miso and it sounded interesting. The dish was beautifully presented, but fell a little flat for me. I didn't get any miso flavor coming through at all. I think perhaps a miso-cashew butter would have been better than just miso in the poaching liquid.  For my main course, I had the cabbage and taleggio ravioli, which were really nicely done. The combo of sauerkraut-esque cabbage with buttery taleggio was perfect for me. Definitely ends up on the sour side, which I personally like.  Station is a little pricey for me to come regularly, but I would come back for sure.

JeMJM96RROuFYVskEJjIvA.text: This restaurant is one of the best farm to table places I have ever been too and one to make point to dine at when in Pittsburgh.  Curtis, the chef and owner, has a wonderful sense and ability to pair foods that bring to life flavors you would not think possible.  We will be back every time we visit Pittsburgh.

8oSsfmyz64g80Srwagtseg.text: One of the best meals I've had in a long time. A lot of skill in the kitchen. I had a flank steak with fried cauliflower. gfViiMWb9XulBBCV1XkP7w.text: Meh. My meal was fine. I had the pheasant breast and sausage and the beet and plum salad. Perfectly agreeable. The portions are quite small. I had a hard time hearing people at my table because the acoustics amplify ambient noise.   Not a great experience, but I did leave after eating everything on my plates. It just didn't take long.

ez-HQlvjZR_16GD3WwtxNA.text: Went there for the first time about a month ago. FSmeAet3ciNtzlUikW2U8w.text: The fact that I live within walking distance from Station is a plus. TAtwM9G1kk2O2CZdqPrwvw.text: Very cool place. Like the space and layout. When you walk in the bar area is inviting and not hipster. Tables are great for people watching here. 9Kd4bQUyl-J9iq5njlIDEw.text: I had a preview of Station at a Yelp event close to a year ago and let me tell you this: I have been DREAMING of that roasted carrot salad since. Thrilled to finally have dinner here.  Atmosphere. Understated and simple. Warm lighting and rustic mixed with industrial makes you just feel hip when you walk in.   Cocktails classic with a twist. I had their version of a Manhattan. Served up with quality ingredients in a Marie Antoinette glass, imbibing could be dangerous. So smooth!! This can also be served on ice. Next I ordered an Old Fashioned. Just as beautiful. Cocktails are a bit in the pricier side, but worth the quality.   I did not order the carrot salad. I know, I had been drooling in my dreams over it, but I was thwarted by the chicken liver mousse. Why, oh why?? I could have ordered all of the small plates. The mousse was divine. Beautifully smooth and ample in portion. I ate it all. ALL. Served with crusty oiled bread and pickled ramps. Friends had the carrot salad, wings confit and beef tongue. Nothing left on our plates.   Next dilemma....entree. I love that there are few items on the menu, but can you put on something I WON'T like? OMG. The struggle was real to decide. I opted with the Tagliatelle. Divine! Which came first? The pork or the egg? I don't care. Their marriage is one that should last forever. Tried a bite of the cod and the look of the burger was mouth watering, too. Pork belly...I'm coming for you!  Dessert. Yeah. I did it, so?!??! Popcorn Panna Cotta. It is a decadent and whimsical as it sounds. Sadly, if I could have got my head in that mason jar like a dog, I would have.   Will I be back to Station? (Don't tell anyone, but I'm camped out here now.)

x2NFEsjvQb_fYgC-3BMl0g.text: I originally started with a three star opinion but I'm hopeful about this place enough for a bonus point. Three stars on a clearly popular and well done spot seems harsh.  But here's the deal.. A cocktail menu at a restaurant needs to have drinks I can sip on with my meal. I ended up ordering the Ruby Queen--beets and vodka, mostly--and I have no idea why I thought that would work out well.  It was super vinegary; I was not prepared for an entire rocks glass of that (although of course I still drank all of it eventually). The cocktail menu is rough on Station for me. Most of it is creative, but includes negroni, manhattan, things that shouldn't take up space on the six or seven option menu.. Especially when there are some expectations from Grit & Grace's super extensive (and delicious) list. Yikes.  I've been eating small basket tastings from Station for the past year at every local function and was always a fan. That has not changed, but I get less excited as the night goes on here. +1 and I spilt the heirloom tomato salad.  It was complete with the super acidic earthy vibe (AND ALL THE DILL!) I've had at each preview but with a pretty little presentation. It was enough to buffer as our food took a little extra time. My crispy chicken was good.. Cooked well. Tender. But I'm a gal for seasoning and wished I had some Trader Joe's 21 Salute on me. That's a little disappointing. Luckily, the lil' dirty bread pudding had enough flavor in a gooey little square for the whole plate. +1 had a burger that he was waaay too into. What else is new. The fries which I stole all of were great though (like, really really great).  I'm definitely coming back to the bar (one of my fav 'tenders is now here!) to give the menu another swing--I'm sure it changes often enough--but might give the food some time before trying again before taking another Gamble (get it, get it). I'm sure this is going to grow to a favorite.

GVjNcD2DKG3yIjmfACfH5A.text: I had the best meal that I've had in a long time here last night.  Pro-tip, ask the waiter what the more adventurous items on the menu are.  I almost got a rather basic dish but was encouraged to try more.  So glad I did!  My pork dish was a deconstruction on an old classic- perfectly cooked with a cannelloni that had some sort of mashed potato esque filling, and a molasses shatter on top that was reminiscent of applesauce just kicked up to 11.  The drinks were perfect!  Don't let the rather been-done decor or branding fool you, this place is legit.  Hoping someone sees this review and hires a better decorator and brand manager, the chef deserves better!

y15139ueF64ckQJyKpCK5w.text: Station is a great addition to Bloomfield. Station is now in what used to be the old D'Amico's restaurant. The interior is just beautiful and there are two rooms-one when you first walk in and the second right next door through a hallway. We started with the heirloom tomato salad. The old bay seasoning in this salad was the perfect touch. The tomatoes and corn were so fresh. For drinks, I had the rodeo cowboy which reminded me of a negroni. Cocktails are around $10-which are about the same at most restaurants in the area. For dinner, that hangar steak was like butter! The potatoes and sauce that came with it were delicious too. My partner in crime had the chicken and he ate every last bit of it! So take that as a good sign!  For desert, we had the popcorn panna cotta. It was decent, but I wish I would have tried the lavender pound cake instead. We paid around $100 for two people with drinks, appetizer, two entrees and desert. I cannot wait to go back as I hear their menu will change with the seasons.

OZLjYhz2G58AtmC98Naa7g.text: "It's no Cracker Barrel," I said to my wife as she suggested we eat at the newest, soon to be hot spot simply because it's good and everyone will eventually know.  "... And they may be so green that the staff isn't developed, and FOH personalities don't yet exist. Surely we should wait until they're established until we go there."  "Don't call me Shirley!" And she was right.   Her name isn't Shirley.   It was ok to eat here, even if today WAS my yearly lap completion day. I FORCED myself to try all four of the signature cocktails, mostly because they weren't just special, but I didn't have anybody sign ANYTHING, not even once on my visit.   Anyhow, the food was good, the service was nominal. And if you think I didn't love every minute of it, you need to reread this review over and over again until you understand sarcasm, or Citizen Kane, whichever comes first.   But seriously. Everything about this spot, right in my neighborhood, is fantastic. I genuinely believe that if you've found your way to these Yelp reviews, and you're not looking for bud light-well done naked burghers-house vodka red bulls-wine from a jug,   You'll like it here.  The beef tongue was unique. The poached apples w/pickled grapes, frisee, and cashews was fantastic. The chicken liver mousse was melt in your mouth good, if a little bit salty-a good thing. The pork tenderloin/pork belly was exactly what it should have been, the lentil salad paired perfectly, and I actually loved the carrots. Lastly the coutlotte, which of course we ordered rare knowing what the cut of meat is, was delicious. As someone who isn't a fan of cauliflower, I found the roasted version served with the meat amazingly delicious. Even though the wife and I drink our dessert, we ordered the lavender pound cake-what a well balanced dessert! As if it was crafted to have flavor profiles and not just attack a sweet tooth. If you want a boring sweet, buy a candy bar, this pound cake has me craving a return visit. Which I hear won't be the same since they exist in the rotational/seasonal availability world. Can't wait!

A-BHPk6ZvuXaxWRJ_zA6tg.text: Glad to be able try Station so soon after it opened. Met my wife and another couple for dinner.  In regards to the cocktails. Between the four of us 2e tried the Manhattan, the Negroni and a cocktail of bourbon, lemon and an ipa. The Negronis were top not. I enjoyed my Manhattan, though I do hope they expand their cocktail menu on our next visit.  For appetizers we shared the heirloom tomato salad and the wings. Highly recommend both. I really enjoyed the cream on the wings.  In regards to entrees we tried the pork belly and roasted pork, chicken with savory bread pudding, hanger steak, and pork shank with pasta. I would say all the meals were good but nothing amazing. We each liked parts of our meals but felt other parts were lacking. I had the pork belly and roasted pork. The pork belly and roasted carrots were great. I felt the roasted pork, while done properly, was a bit over salted.   None of us had room for dessert, but the couple next to us both said the popcorn and the loaf cake were very good (they both looked very tasty).  Highly recommended. Glad to have new type of restaurant in the Bloomfield area. Will definitely head back.

Z_V0XVv5vVqD08cAWeeL8A.text: First off, Station is like nothing that is around it in Bloomfield. As a resident I am THRILLED that it exists. I would go here every day if I could. I've gone for dinner, for drinks, for brunch,  I've taken friends, new and old, and convinced them that they HAVE to try the chicken wings, but if there's chicken on the menu, its most likely incredible. Brunch is the last thing I've tried here, and I had food envy of every single person at the table while I ate the best chicken brunch plate ever. Christian the bartender is a large part of the reason we kept going back (and sitting at the bar) - he really knows his stuff and makes great drinks. The very few times I've veered from the El Chapo, my favorite drink in existence here, he's led me to a great one.   Just reading through the reviews, I would say that some of the prices are a bit steep for dinner entrees, but we can still walk out after eating a burger, chicken wings and a round of drinks for about $50. The happy hour prices are lower.   I think its great to have a place in Bloomfield where we can walk in for just a casual quick drink, bring friends for a great dinner or head there for brunch on the weekends and I hope it stays around because I love walking to a place that has great quality food.

l14yNdhaFs8Zuzz7g0X59Q.text: This place is a solid B and a good addition to Bloomfield, however food is not anything to gush over. I had the agnolotti which was more or less four ravioli doused in breadcrumbs. While it's not that exciting, the burger and fries are a pretty solid choice that anyone would be satisfied with.  Craig, the Bartender, was great and made custom "Craig's Special" whiskey drinks that our table enjoyed. One recommendation would be to add more of a wine selection to the menu, it's one choice for each type of red/white and they weren't the greatest options.

UphlcCvp-UUFydz-gbPWGw.text: It's Saturday night of Thanksgiving weekend and you've got a group of 11 people for dinner...good luck, right? Well, Station hooked us up! We got the reservation, and then had 2 additions to our party, which they accommodated graciously when we called to update. Seated us right on time, maybe even a little early. Great service - attentive, friendly, timely, which isn't always the case with a large group. Food was spectacular. Some of the samplings we had that we all enjoyed: Crispy wings (so crispy and flavorful!), chicken liver mousse (the toasted sourdough was what made it for me), Roasted Octopus (just YUM!), Short Rib (tender & perfectly cooked), and the tagliatelle (perfection). Both desserts were delicious, but the popcorn panna cotta takes it to a whole other level. The only thing keeping me from 5 stars is that they were out of apparently every lettuce they had so no salads available. But hey, it was Saturday night of Thanksgiving weekend after all. bI-b5vOraUORQNXBMH73mg.text: I've read all the reviews on here, after a friend made a reservation at Station for 5 of us. We started with a few small plates: the Roasted Carrot, Chicken Liver Mousse and Crispy Wings. The Mousse was quite good, especially with the buttery sourdough that accompanied it. I had the Station Burger, the only under $20 Large Plate, just because I was feeling burger. It came on a nicely textured brioche bun with perfectly crisped fries and a delicious onion jam. The huge onion ring on top was actually redundant, and just made the towering burger harder to eat. It was cooked exactly as I ordered, but the beef didn't have any distinct flavor, and I've had better burgers for half the price. Two others in my party had the Tagliatelle, which they both seemed to like, and the Crispy Skin Chicken, which I think was given a thumbs up. We sat in the main large dining room up against a corrugated metal wall, and it was VERY loud. y21KfFebCsobjD-mLDJtZQ.text: I dined here with my family for my birthday earlier this year, and the dinner left us utterly delighted. This lovely restaurant is sort of divided into two sections, with a beautiful bar area and some seating on one side and a proper dining area on the other. Literally the only negative thing I can say about the space is that the chairs aren't the most comfortable ones I've ever sat in, but that wasn't a deal breaker by any means.  My family and I shared an array of appetizers and entrees, which included: chicken liver mousse, corned beef tongue, a salad, duck and bean ravioli, a crispy skin chicken dinner, and a sizzling steak. With a side of cocktails, of course. (Disclaimer: I believe Station's menu changes on a regular basis, so I can't promise that the items we ordered are still there.) And we were watched over by a very helpful and attentive waiter who did a great job answering everyone's questions and providing information as we narrowed down the entire menu - which all looked amazing! - into a handful of orders.  All of the items that we ordered were as amazing as they sounded. I knew the mousse was good due to a tasting event I had attended the year prior, although I also knew it was strong enough in flavor that I wouldn't want an entire serving of it to myself. I definitely recommend sharing this dish, at least during a first visit. Everything else that we ordered, I was trying for the first time.   The corned beef tongue surprised me the most, as it was far tastier than I expected. This dish was served with toast and toppings as well, so the overall combination of crunchy bread and tender meat was delightful. Between the liver mousse and the corned beef tongue, we were feeling pretty good and surprisingly filling up before our main courses arrived.  The main dinners were so tasty that we pretty much kept on going and stuffed ourselves on the delicious food. Just as memorable as the appetizers was the chicken dinner (that may not be available currently according to the website), which primarily featured melt-in-your-mouth, beautifully seasoned cuts of chicken. I personally had ordered the duck and bean ravioli, which were - for lack of a better word - unique. I haven't seen many other restaurants combine duck and beans, let alone serve them together inside a ravioli. The flavor profile of these ingredients was very tasty, though. A fresh salad and a tender steak were also brought to our table, and all four orders were shared and sampled by my very happy family.  If you're looking for a new place to try, I definitely recommend Station, which has some of the best dishes and greatest flavor profiles I've come across in the city so far. The fantastic food and lovely waitstaff in a charming atmosphere meant that everyone in my family had a wonderful night out for my birthday. Thanks for having us, Station - I hope I have a chance to eat here again soon!

0naBW98bi_3VeyX0BlsOlQ.text: My wife and I had dinner here on a Saturday evening.  Reservations:  We made reservations for 7PM via Opentable.  As we approached 7, we realized that we were going to be late.  We called and the hostess was able to push our reservation back by 30 minutes.  She was incredibly pleasant and professional.  Arriving at the Restaurant:  This is going to sound nit-picky but the front door is a bit bizarre.  When you come through the door the hostess is immediately on the left, which promotes some congestion.  As we stood waiting, another couple came to the door.  Because the door opens inward, it was a bit awkward as we were blocking their entrance.  The dark paint and industrial feel is inviting, and there is a long bar is set-up on the left.  The bar seemed comfortable and the spirits are displayed nicely.  I noticed a nice selection of brown-liquor.  Waitress: Nice, pleasant, explained the menu items and cocktails well.  Cocktails:  Excellent.  I had the Oaxaca Manhattan which was made with mezcal, super good and the smoky flavor of the mezcal worked well with the drink.  My wife had the Maple Sazerac which was also very good.  I was afraid that it was going to be overly sweet, but not the case.   Appetizers:  One Excellent, One slightly missed the mark.   Carrot salad: The carrot salad was probably one of the best salads I've had in recent memory.  The carrots were cold but perfectly cooked (not too crunchy, not too soft) the greens were delicious, and the dressing was light but flavorful.  The star of the salad was the chick-pea (i think) fritter.  This was the only part of the salad that was warm, but it worked great with the dish.     Chicken Liver Mousse: We felt a bit let-down by this dish.  The mousse itself was a bit under-seasoned (this is perhaps nit-picking) but the real problem was with the way the mousse was served.  They provide you two large pieces of the most greasy toast you've ever eaten.  I'm no prude, if i ate that toast by itself i'd love it, but it was just too damn rich combining the mousse with the overly buttery toast.  The toast takes away from the mousse instead of letting it be the star.  Admittedly we ate most of the mousse (which was a very large portion - perhaps too much honestly) and had extra toast brought out, but it was just overwhelmingly rich and greasy with the toast.    Entrees: Excellent.  Roasted Octopus: I don't know why I worry about ordering octopus because every time i have it it turns out quite good.  The texture was tender, and the white bean puree was a nice sauce.  It was served with some bean fritters and kale greens that were flavorful and soft - likely cooked for a while.  I'd order this again.  Tagliatelle: My wife ordered this and only shared with me a small bite but it was quite good.  The pasta was likely fresh-made and the sauce / pork was super tasty.  The dish was fairly rich with a soft egg, and parmesean cheese.  The pasta grabbed the sauce and pork perfectly.  Very good - wish she had shared more.  We did not have dessert.  Conclusion: This is a good restaurant worthy of a try.  The value for money felt right to me, and aside the toast with the mousse, i can't honestly fault any of the food.  The cocktails were top-notch and the service was very good.  My only concern was that we went on a Saturday night where the weather was nice and yet the restaurant wasn't full - didn't even feel that busy between 7:30 - 8:30.  The bar was mostly empty when we left as-well.   Hopefully it was just a slow night relatively speaking.

1ua55hqPt4zXtK5l13uBEQ.text: This place is really like nothing Bloomfield has ever seen before, yet they really make you feel comfortable with a casual vibe, just like Bloomfield itself! fLRuEEyGGlau8_Ha5lEOig.text: Despite consistent Bloomfield efforts to Keep Pittsburgh Shitty, Station enters the neighborhood as the restaurant that no one wants, but everyone needs. As a resident of the area, I'll admit that I wasn't totally sold when I heard about Chef Curtis Gamble's classy casual yuppie hip dining joint injected in the heart of Bloomfield. After only being open for a week, though, the warm hospitality and enthusiastic attitudes of the restaurant are already spreading the great reputation that it deserves.  The owners are committed, friendly, and eager to meet their new neighborhood. The service was perfect--not too obtrusive, not too serious, and never neglecting (even in a nearly packed house). The drinks were refreshing, and the food was spectacular.  The tagliatelle is handmade using the pasta maker left over from whatever old Italian joint was in the space decades ago. The heirloom tomato salad features fresh dill and an Old Bay mustard. The chicken is perfectly crisped and complemented with bread pudding and grilled lettuce.  And the space rules. Relax at the bar with a cocktail, walk in for a nice meal near the bar, or make a reservation in the dining room for a more intimate atmosphere. I hope Station sticks around the area, mostly because it's nice to be able to walk to a fine-dining restaurant for a meal and cocktails without worrying about how I'm going to crawl home.

We were immediately approached by the bartender who couldn't have been nicer. They have great happy hour drink deals so I got an aperol spritz and my friend got a glass of the rose (both pictured). We decided to sit outside and enjoy the sun, and we were promptly brought both our drinks and a caraffe of water. Mine even came with a metal straw to deter pollution, so a major plus for Station!!  The spritz is really delicious. I lived for a year in Padova, Italy, which is the birthplace of the aperol spritz, and I can honestly say that Station has done a good job of getting the right balance of prosecco and aperol! It's completely refreshing and even has an orange peel for that extra burst of flavor.  The food menu also looks delicious. The "small plates" menu is pictured, and I'm personally looking forward to coming back for the eggplant caponata!  A high recommend, I'll certainly come back next time I'm in the burgh!

Vyj4plWglF4lT2fvQ2H_qg.text: You know the food was damn good when you can't stop thinking about it days later!   I had heard very positive rumblings in the Pittsburgh vegan community about Station's vegan Sloppy Joe, and already experiencing their stellar cocktail offerings, I knew it would be a great place to enjoy my birthday dinner. In addition to the Sloppy Joe, my husband and I also enjoyed the Carrot Bolognese.   Both items were SO delicious! The Sloppy Joe was perfectly seasoned and served with Potato-Patch-esque french fries. The Carrot Bolognese was "meaty" - even though of course no meat was involved! My Corpse Reviver #2 cocktail was a refreshing choice to wash it all down with.  My only (so small) gripe are the choice of seats in the dining room. I noticed when making my online reservation you can choose a high-top table in the bar instead of the wooden seats in the dining room - I will do that next time and I'm sure my back will leave just as happy as my stomach!

0faIYXy6k9jGO9YoDV3LvA.text: Great place for candle lit dinners in the Bloomfield neck of the woods of Pittsburgh.   We started off with an old fashioned, which was absolutely amazing. The Dark and Stormy, on the other hand, tasted a bit more like flat ginger ale with lime juice.  Actually, my girlfriend started out with the Dark and Stormy and didn't like it/finish it and got the Old Fashioned. It had potential, but I would go with the Old Fashioned.  The chicken liver mousse was very delicious. It was a cream cheese consistency and was garnished with something that was crunchy, crisp, and sour (sunchokes?). It had such a smooth texture and just melts in your mouth. This is no ordinary "pate" which look like gritty cat food pate. This is definitely a must have here if you like pate.  I didn't have the salad, but my girlfriend and her boyfriend got  the roasted carrots salad and local greens salad and ate then clean so... I presume it was good. The local greens looked very fresh and the greens in the bowl had a lot of volume to it (ie greens were not wilted). I'm not much of a veggie kinda gal.  We all got the hanger steak which was very flavorful, but it was pretty chewy but that tends to be how hanger steaks are I suppose.  I still highly recommend it.  The Popcorn Panna Cotta was surprisingly delicious. I mean, I knew it would be good just not my thing since I don't have much of a sweet tooth for desserts in general but I was wrong. The panna cotta was server in a small mason jar and topped with caramel popcorn. It was very very good. Just imagine a delicious creamy custard topped with crunchy caramel popcorn.  The lavender pound cake was pretty good, but I'd prefer the former. I didn't really taste the coconut pudding... it was two thick cuts of pound cake topped with some diced caramelized pineapples. Maybe the pudding was baked in to the cake? But I couldn't taste the coconut. The lavender was very subtle. It is very dense and moist cake, so this may have your name on it if you like pound cake, but I have also had dried out pound cake.  For four people, the Panna Cotta got devoured, whereas there was still 25% if the cake left that we didn't want which I ate anyways just to get rid of.  Wrapping up : Old Fashioned, Chicken Liver Mousse, Grilled Hanger Steak, and Popcorn Panna Cotta would be the course I'd recommend.  In fact, I'd just get two Panna Cottas instead of one of each like we did.  My girlfriend also said the salmon was very good, but she prefers the hanger steak if this nugget of information may help.

BA2c54ZMNBf_U-5jsQkGsw.text: Why is this place not packed every night of the week?!   Station is truly a gem - hands down the best meal I have had all year from start to finish.   It is not a cheap place, but it is absolutely worth every penny. We did the $40 three course tasting menu.  Tasting isn't the right word - it's a full meal.  I had expected tiny portions based on some of the reviews and the overall style of the menu, but actually found the portions to be ample and left full and happy.       I started with the roasted carrot salad with fresh cheese, harissa, pomegranate curd, chickpea fritter, and watercress.  The carrots were roasted to perfection and all of the ingredients in the dish worked together to make a well balanced and filling starter.   My companions went with the beet and fig salad.  The server explained when we ordered that the figs didn't look great that day and so the chef was substituting plums.   While they were disappointed about the missing figs initially, they both thoroughly enjoyed the salad.  Clean plates all around.     Second course was a medium rare short rib entree, which wasn't on the regular menu, but was an option on the tasting menu.  I can't remember all the bits in the menu description; but again, I was pleasantly surprised by the dish and it's sophistication.  I expected a hunk of braised short rib and some veggies/potatoes, which is what you usually get when you order short rib.  What I got was an artfully arranged array with a decent portion of sliced short rib that was cooked just right.  It looked as good as it tasted and we all cleaned our plates.     Third course was a lavender pound cake with poached pineapple and coconut pudding.  Again, the portion was ample and the dish was beautiful.  It was tasty too - a strange and creative combo of flavors that really worked well in the end.  My companions got the popcorn panna cotta, which was also delightful.  The panna cotta was just the right texture and the popcorn topping added some contrast.  Neither dessert was overly sweet, which I appreciated.   My only suggestion on the entire meal would be that the jar the panna cotta is served in is a little awkward.  It would be easier to eat if it were shorter and wider, spreading out the popcorn topping a bit.    Service was top notch from the bar to the table.  Our server was well-matched to the place - with poise and polish, but not stuffy arrogance.  We will be back, that's for sure!

69HrD9n3Af-UACyoBCj46Q.text: I selected Station for a graduation dinner with 8 people, because it had delicious looking meat options, but also had a reputation for providing strong vegetarian/vegan options. The drinks were inventive and tasty, the server did an excellent job, and the entire meal from appetizer, through main course and dessert was fabulous -- everyone raved about their meals. The James Barkhurst (Dos maderas 5+3, Salignac cognac, Barolo Vermouth, Butterscoth dolin blanc vermouth, coffee porter), and a drink called the Penicillin stand out from the several that I sampled. The Roasted Carrot appetizer was truly amazing, a hearty blend of flavors and textures, and the best of the first courses tried. They also had a seasonal chilled cucumber soup (smoked trout roe, charred cucumber skins, pressure cooked ancho and a yogurt panna cotta). Interestingly the baby romaine salad with its buttermilk dressing reminded one of the guys of a great burger, without having any meat in it. Two people had the station burger, served with onion rings and ideal crispy, seasoned french fries bearing bits of real potato skin. They were great dipped in the asiago fondue that came with the burger. Two people had the vegetarian carrot bolognese, which they enjoyed. One had the spare rib appetizer for his meal, which ended up being a huge portion with four large ribs. Both the hanger steak and the scallops on the prix fixe menu were excellent.  The hanger steak was perfectly cooked and delicious, with its cauliflower, roasted mushroom, shallot and roasted garlic custard. But the scallops were unbelievably good, served over rhubarb jus with pickled ramp relish, white asparagus and green garlic fritter. Even though there were only three scallops, the entire dish was deeply satisfying, particularly the asparagus in the sweet-tart sauce and I thought the amounts of each element were perfectly satisfying. I appreciated that they did not just pay lip service to offering tiny bits of (tasty) vegetables, as often happens in nice restaurants, but gave enough for a balanced meal that stimulated the palate.  The lavendar pound cake with coconut pudding and candied pineapple was delicious and everyone happily helped the person that ordered it finish hers (it was a pretty large dessert). But the star of the desserts was the caramel caramel corn panna cotta, a rich satisfying custard topped with the most amazing caramel with caramel corn on top. My prix fixe meal (roasted carrots, scallops, panna cotta) was the best meal that I have had in a very long time, and at $45 was a real bargain.

lS4JZ8IEsbImhF1vnANyeQ.text: The food is definitely the star at Station. The descriptions on the somewhat limited menu are creative and the execution delivers. An Heirloom tomato salad was elevated with the introduction of Old Bay custard and sweet corn and though the croutons were tasty, they seemed a bit out of place in this particular salad. The crispy chicken breast and leg was a home run. As if the tender chicken wasn't tasty enough, the addition of grilled baby lettuce, dirty bread pudding, corn puree and buttermilk vinaigrette made it all the more interesting. As good as the savory dishes were, the lavender pound cake for dessert was my favorite. It was smartly coupled with coconut pudding and pineapple. The restaurant is conveniently located along Liberty Avenue in Bloomfield, a great neighborhood that lacks creative destination restaurants like this one. The interior is modern, industrial and warm all at once with a pained exposed brick wall, cool lights strung about, but kept appropriately dim. While the food and interior design are winners, I did find a three drawbacks, all of which are fixable, and hopefully will be adjusted as this new restaurant finds it place. (1) The price of wine seems excessive, as there's no reason it should be more than other high-end places, such as Casbah, that known for their wine selection. And the more stunning thing is the lack of value for bottles. An $11 glass is $50 by the bottle and a $15 glass is $69 for a bottle. The pours are 5 ounces, by the way, according to a server. (2) The server was nice and efficient, but we could have done without the introductory spiel to guide us through the menu, which is very small to start with. That shtick is corporate-like and shouldn't be in chef-driven restaurants like this. Save the spiel for those who ask. (3) This one is a bit more difficult to put a finger on, but despite the cool surroundings, the restaurant lacked a good "vibe," especially in the dining room, which wasn't particular busy. There was no music, so perhaps some livey (but not too loud) music would add to it. There also seemed to be a lot of "empty" space that otherwise could be filled with tables, which didn't help in this respect, but perhaps management plans to add more tables once the restaurant is open longer. Perhaps the server will also add to the charm of the place as they get their groove.

The bar area is beautiful...I loved the giant mirror backed bar and it immediately have a warm, friendly and cool vibe. We started with cocktails (old fashioned) which were good.   Then for starters, we had the roasted carrot salad and some kind of cold green soup. Honestly, I could have just had the roasted cauliflower it was so good, but the steak was a tender and tasty complement.  My better half had carrot bolognese pasta which was also wonderful.  To finish, we shared a popcorn panna cotta and a lavender pound cake.  The combination of the caramelized popcorn with the creamy texture of the panna cotta was a match made in heaven.   And that lavender pound cake was something straight off "The Great British Bake Off".  Wow, was it good.  Service was professional and on point.   This is one of those restaurants I'd love to pick up and move to my neighborhood in NYC so I could eat there all the time.

Tn-0_U8fIzvfydsYaviF3w.text: You know a restaurant is good when you're still thinking about your meal weeks later. It took me waaay too long to try Station, but better late than never right? Definitely check them out when you're in the Bloomfield area!

-ffSGlSQrCRATivJrQrbvw.text: My boyfriend and I decided to go to Station for date night this evening. We ordered the beef tartare and grilled pork rib small plates to share, he order the burger and I ordered the grilled hanger steak.  The starters: The beef tartare was good, the beef itself wasn't as outstanding as I would have liked, but the dish came together beautifully, and the spiced crackers were great. The grilled pork rib is where things started going a little sideways. The meat itself was done perfectly, but the sauce was a touch on the weird side. I am a huge fan of sezchuan peppercorn, but I really don't think it worked with the rest of the dish on top of which some bites were beautifully balanced, others were not.  The mains: His - Between the asiago fondue, onion ring, and onion jam, the beef, which should be the star of the show, got lost in the mix. That and the stacked burger is a somewhat absurd height. The fries were to die for.  Mine - The hanger steak was grilled perfectly, the fried cauliflower was thickly battered, was interesting, but quickly became soggy. I would have greatly preferred a roasted cauliflower. The mushrooms were perfect. There were two slivers of onion, and they were both tasty. The garlic custard needed way more garlic and way less custard. The jus used to coat the bottom of the plate was far too abundant and far too rich. I wound up moving the majority of my meal to the edge of my plate so I could enjoy the flavors of the components of my meal without losing them in the sauces.  Overall, it is very obvious that Station uses high quality produce and meats, but those ingredients were not allowed to shine and were buried under too many flavors and unnecessary rich sauces. Everything we had was very rich with little done to balance the richness. I craved some acidity by the end of it.   We will be back to try other options on the menu at some point, and I really am hoping the second attempt goes better than this one. As someone who loves using quality ingredients in my own kitchen and letting them shine through, I'm hoping the next time we're there, we walk out with a better impression. Right now, both of our meals are sitting heavy on us.

7GDaE7GqWv0qdndP6p4BAg.text: We went to Station a few months ago when a group of friends and I chose it as our "upscale" dinner place.  We have had great luck with cheap and casual eats in Pittsburgh so we were excited to try a little bit of a more formal meal in this great city.  We arrived a little bit after the dinner rush, so the place wasn't crowded or crazy and we got a lot of great attention from our server.  Since there were four of us, we decided to have their prix fixe menu and each of us picked one.   I won't go into great detail for the meal, because the items are not standard menu items, so you won't get what I ordered by this time. What I can tell you is that each dish was wonderfully executed and the wine options worked perfectly with each dish.   One of the specials included the chicken liver mousse (which is in the main menu) and that was a revelation for me. I am not a huge fan of liver, although I do like organ meat normally, and this dish managed to convinced me to try more liver mousse. The taste that turn me off liver (that iron-like earthiness) was perfectly balance with all the other ingredients creating a luscious creamy spread that we loved. Our only complain is that we needed more bread to spread it on!  Another highlight was the fact that the vegetarian and vegan dishes we got (I ordered the vegetarian options) were as well planned and executed as the meat dishes. So many times I've been to a restaurant with a great reputation and they usually are just good at pork, or beef, and everything else is an afterthought. This shows a commitment to all the food they serve, and a willingness to please their customers.  After having such a great meal, we told our server how much we loved what we got, and they offered to send us a recipe for one of our favorite items.
